awd_titl_txt: SBE-UKRI: Collaborative Research: The Role of Environment in Social Transformation
awd_abstract_narration:
Archaeologists have studied societal collapse, working to unravel the multiple social, political, and environmental factors that contributed to the breakdown of long term political systems. Yet, major questions remain unanswered. Interdisciplinary research has postulated that potentially severe drought episodes may play an important role in this process. Despite the strong patterns in the paleoclimate record, it is less clear how elite and non-elite populations responded to the impacts of drought. Research has demonstrated that the collapse can be varied with the timing of abandonment different across geographic regions likely representing distinct decision-making processes of populations for each site. In some cases settlements are able to persist through several droughts although the mechanisms of that survival are not well-understood. These issues are relevant to current climate challenges, as past patterns may serve as lessons from past societies that successfully or unsuccessfully adapted to the impacts of climate. This award will further international collaboration and further training of students.

This project will identify the human responses to climatic challenges in a way that moves beyond the simple narrative of 'drought caused collapse' to determine what adaptation strategies were adopted as a population faced climate instability. To get at the human responses to climate variation, the reseachers ask: How did a population change their land use strategies in the event of extreme drought? How did they continue occupation following a collapse? Did they change how they farmed and lived? These questions will be addressed by examining the numbers and timing of burials to gauge how population sizes changed through time. Artifacts and monumental construction will be assessed to understand how people decided to use their resources with respect to trade and construction episodes and how these changed with climate pressures. Environments will be reconstructed using geochemical and microfossil (pollen, charcoal and algal remains) signatures in lake sediments that archive the nature of the surrounding environments at the time they were deposited.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public for the following award:

 Project Title: SBE-UKRI: Collaborative Research: The Role of Environment in Social Transformation

PI: Jaime Awe
Awardee: Northern Arizona University
Award Number: 2136333
Award Ends:08/31/2024

 

The Northern Arizona University/Awe component of the SBE-UKRI collaborative research on the role of environment in social transformation was responsible for excavations at the archaeological sites of Baking Pot and Cahal Pech in western Belize. Other components of the project included paleo-ecological research in the Belize River valley by Dr. Bronwen Whitney from Northumbria University in England, and the dating of construction sequences to determine architectural energetics at Baking Pot and Cahal Pech under the direction of Dr. Julie Hoggarth of Baylor University.

 Excavations at Cahal Pech and Baking Pot focused on open areas, major plazas and monumental architecture in the epicentres of the two sites. Our excavations, coupled with preliminary results of our 14C dating, presently indicate that labor investments in monumental architecture at Cahal Pech were considerable during the Preclassic (900 BCE – 200 CE), Early Classic (200 – 600 CE), and early phase of the Late Classic (600 – 750 CE) periods. By Terminal Classic times (750 – 850 CE), Cahal Pech witnessed minimal construction efforts, and the site began to experience a protracted decline and subsequent abandonment by the end of the ninth century.

 In contrast to Cahal Pech, construction efforts at Baking Pot were limited during Preclassic and Early Classic times, followed by a boom in construction activity during the Late Classic period, then limited construction efforts at the start of the Terminal Classic period. Baking Pot is eventually abandoned at the onset of the Early Postclassic period (1000 – 1100 CE) and then reoccupied during Late Postclassic times (1200 – 1500 CE).

 The completion of the dating component of the project, which is being directed by Dr. Hoggarth at Baylor University, will serve to confirm the temporality of these construction efforts at the two sites while results of the paleo-ecological research, directed by Dr. Bronwen Whitney of Northumbria University in England, will allow us to determine whether climate change contributed to the abandonment of these two cities at the end of the Terminal Classic/Early Postclassic periods. Results of our multidisciplinary study also has implications for modern communities in the developing and developed world as we begin to experience the impacts of climate change, as well as the strategies we can employ to improve our resilience in an ever-changing environment.

Modified by: Jaime J Awe
